node.title: Unleashing AI Innovation: Highlights from Our Internal Hackathon on AI Agents & Automation
node.content:
Innovation thrives where creativity meets technology, and our recent Internal Hackathon on AI Agents and Automation was a true showcase of that spirit. In just one week, a team of talented developers, engineers, and AI enthusiasts came together to push the limits of AI-powered automation. The result? Cutting-edge prototypes that streamline workflows, enhance productivity, and transform the way we interact with technology.

Why AI Agents & Automation?
As businesses seek efficiency and innovation, AI and automation are key to staying ahead. Our hackathon focused on creating AI agents to simplify tasks, boost productivity, and reduce manual effort. From smart assistants to automated security tracking, the prototypes show how AI can transform industries.


Standout Projects from the Hackathon:

Group Projects:

1. Group Phoenix â€“ AI-Powered Personal Assistant with n8n for Task Automation

In todayâ€™s fast-paced world, managing tasks efficiently is essential.  Group Phoenix developed an AI-powered assistant, built on n8n, automates scheduling, email management, and web queries through simple text commands, enhancing productivity and efficiency.

How It Works:

  1. Chat Trigger â€“ Activated when a user sends a message.
  2. Input Processing â€“ Formats messages and maintains session context.
  3. AI-Powered Actions â€“ Uses OpenAIâ€™s Chat Model to interpret and respond intelligently.
  4. Seamless Integration â€“ Connects with Google Calendar, Outlook, Gmail, and SerpAPI for scheduling, emails, and real-time data retrieval.
  5. Instant Responses â€“ Delivers processed results efficiently.

Key Features

  • Simple and intuitive text-based command processing.
  • Smart AI-powered decision-making with memory buffer context.
  • Effortless integration with essential productivity tools.
  • Continuous conversation memory for personalized and coherent assistance.

Harness the power of n8n and AI to streamline your daily workflow. Let your AI assistant handle routine tasks while you focus on what truly matters.


2. Team Sentinels â€“ Automating Contact Us Form Handling with AI and Task Management


Team Sentinels developed an innovative solution to automate the handling of Contact-Us form submissions. The solution categorizes inquiries, sends timely responses, and creates tasks for the relevant teams to ensure smooth tracking and follow-up.

Workflow Breakdown:

  1. Webhook Trigger: Captures data when a form is submitted.
  2. AI-Powered Categorization: Uses Google Gemini to classify inquiries and create tailored responses.
  3. Email Notifications: Sends an acknowledgment email to the user, and the respective team (HR, Sales, Support, etc.) receives notifications for relevant inquiries.
  4. Google Tasks: Creates tasks and tracks their status, ensuring no request is forgotten.
  5. Conditional Logic: Automates task updates, sending reminders for overdue tasks.

Key Features:

  • AI-driven categorization of inquiries.
  • Automated task creation and management.
  • Efficient follow-up reminders to ensure prompt action.
This solution eliminates manual labor, helping businesses manage inquiries in an automated and structured way.    


Individual Projects:

3. AI-Powered Security Automation â€“ Extract, Analyze & Track Vulnerabilities (By: Vijaya kumari)

In cybersecurity, AI-driven automation can vastly improve vulnerability management. 
This solution uses AI to analyze OWASP ZAP reports, automatically 
categorizes vulnerabilities, and integrates them 
into GitHub issues for easy tracking and resolution.

Workflow Steps:

  • Extract vulnerabilities from OWASP ZAP reports.
  • Use AI (GPT-4o-mini) to categorize and analyze findings.
  • Automatically create GitHub issues for each vulnerability.

Benefits:

  • Faster and more accurate security tracking.
  • Automated parsing of security reports.
  • Consistent vulnerability monitoring and remediation.
This project brings efficiency and scalability to security teams, enabling better vulnerability management.         
                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                         
4. Automated API Collection Creation â€“ AI-Powered Fast API to Postman (By: Fatima Zahara)

This project automates the extraction of API endpoints from Fast API applications and generates structured Postman collections, reducing the need for manual API documentation.

How it works:

  • Scans FastAPI apps for endpoints.
  • AI structures the data into Postman-compatible formats.                      
  • The collection is uploaded directly to Postman.

Benefits:

  • Eliminates manual effort in API documentation.
  • Reduces errors in endpoint testing.
  • Enhances API testing efficiency.

5. AI-Powered Cucumber Scenario Generation (By: Arun Kumar)

This tool automates the creation of Cucumber scenarios by extracting user stories from GitHub issues and converting them into structured test scenarios. It integrates with GitHub Actions to keep the test cases up-to-date in real-time.

Key Features:

  • Automated scenario creation from GitHub issues.
  • Integration with CI/CD pipelines.
  • Real-time updates for consistent testing.



Whatâ€™s Next in AI-Driven QA Automation?

Building on these AI-powered innovations, the next phase focuses on developing a multi-agent automation framework to further enhance software testing. This framework will intelligently manage Cucumber scenario generation, test execution, and reporting, ensuring seamless automation for both functional and security testing.

With this approach, AI agents will work collaboratively to optimize testing workflows, reduce manual effort, and improve accuracyâ€”paving the way for a smarter and more efficient QA process.



6. AI PC Assistant â€“ Boosting Productivity with Desktop Automation (By: Nayeem)

This AI assistant enhances Windows PC interaction by managing applications, files, and automation workflows using natural language commands.

Key Features:

  • Open/close applications and manage files.
  • AI decision-making for context-aware actions.
  • User-friendly GUI with real-time screen monitoring.


This assistant is designed to streamline PC management and enhance productivity through AI.



7. Scrape Flow: A Framework for Multi-Agent AI System: (By: Faiz Ali)                                                                                                                      
AI-driven automation is evolving, and Scrape Flow takes it a step further by enabling multi-agent collaboration for web scraping, research, and content creation. Built on crew AI, this framework offers flexibility, customization, and seamless execution.

 Why Scrape Flow?
  •  Multi-Agent System â€“ Uses crew AI to coordinate AI agents for complex workflows
  •  YAML-Based Customization â€“ Easily define agent roles & tasks
  •  Ready-to-Use Workflows â€“ Automates research, reporting, and blog writing
  •  Simple Execution â€“ Just run crew ai run to start the process
  •  Extensible â€“ Add custom tools for enhanced agent capabilities
 Whether youâ€™re automating data collection or streamlining content generation, Scrape Flow makes AI teamwork effortless!



8. Streamlining HR with an AI-Powered Chatbot Using Microsoft Copilot in Teams(By:Sameena )

This HR chatbot leverages Microsoft Copilot within Microsoft Teams to automate HR tasks like answering queries about policies and benefits.

Steps to Create the Bot:

  1. Set up the bot using Microsoft Copilot Studio (formerly Power Virtual Agents)
  2. Define topics and integrate HR-specific knowledge.
  3. Deploy and monitor the bot in Teams for employee interaction.

 
Benefits:
  • Improves HR efficiency by automating repetitive tasks
  • Enhances employee engagement by providing quick answers.
  • Alleviates HR workload and improves response efficiency.
            

9. WhatsApp Personal Shopping Assistant â€“ AI-Powered Convenience (By: Shaik Azgar)

This Python-based chatbot integrates Twilioâ€™s API and OpenAIâ€™s GPT to offer a personalized shopping experience on WhatsApp, tracking prices and availability, and sending real-time notifications about deals and restocks.

Features:

  • WhatsApp integration for seamless messaging.
  • AI-driven recommendations and responses.
  • Tracks product prices and alerts users on price drops.
This assistant automates shopping tasks, making the process more efficient and personalized for users.

                                                                                                                                                     

10. AI-Gmail Agent â€“ Smart Email Management (By: Hemanth)

The AI Gmail Agent uses Lang Chain and Groq to simplify email tasks like drafting, updating, and sending emails, making email management faster and more efficient.

Features:

  • AI-powered email drafting and management.
  • Automates repetitive email tasks.
  • User-friendly interface built with Dash.

This solution significantly boosts email productivity by reducing manual effort.


11. Resume Screening Agent (By: Sabiha Sultana)

AI-powered agent to streamline the recruitment process. This agent screens resumes against job descriptions, ranks candidates based on relevance, and automatically invites qualified candidates for interviews.

Process:

  • AI analyses resumes and ranks them.
  • Shortlisted candidates are emailed to the hiring manager.
  • Upon approval, interview invitations are sent.

This innovation dramatically reduces hiring time and enhances recruitment efficiency.



Key Takeaways & Reflections
The AI Agents & Automation Hackathon showcased how AI can revolutionize automation across various domains. In just one week, teams built functional prototypes that streamlined workflows, enhanced productivity, and even revolutionized Quality Assurance (QA) with AI-powered testing, highlighting the immense potential of AI in business operations.

Projects in HR automation, cybersecurity, customer service, and AI-driven QA demonstrated how intelligent automation can reduce manual effort, improve accuracy, and optimize processes. As we continue refining these solutions, our goal is to integrate multi-agent automation frameworks that drive efficiency, scalability, and seamless AI-powered execution.

ðŸ’¡ Got an idea or challenge? Letâ€™s collaborate to turn it into a powerful solution! Reach out to us at connect@appnetwise.com and letâ€™s shape the future together.

node.title: Self-Contained Systems: A Modern Approach to Software Architecture
node.content:
In the ever-evolving landscape of software architecture, while microservices have dominated discussions for over a decade, alternative architectural patterns have emerged to address their limitations. One such approach is Self-Contained Systems (SCS), first documented by Stefan Tilkov and other architects at scs-architecture.org.

The Microservices Misconception

When tech giants pioneered microservices around 2010, everyone wanted to copy their success. But here's the catch: breaking an application into tiny pieces doesn't automatically make it better.

Think of it like this: If you have a messy room, cutting it into smaller rooms doesn't solve the problemâ€”it just gives you many messy rooms to manage. The same goes for software. Many teams ended up with what we now call a "distributed mess": too many services, too few developers, and plenty of headaches.

The lesson? Size isn't everything. What matters is building services that make sense for your team and business. Sometimes bigger, well-organized services are better than many tiny ones.

Key Takeaway: Focus on what works for your team, not what worked for Netflix or Amazon. Your architecture should match your resources and needs.The Hidden Costs of Microservices

While microservices promise flexibility and scalability, they come with significant challenges:

  1. Communication overhead through synchronous API dependencies
  2. Increased latency and failure risks inherent to distributed systems
  3. Complex debugging requiring sophisticated distributed tracing
  4. High maintenance burden due to inter-service dependencies



Enter Self-Contained Systems

Self-Contained Systems (SCS) offer a middle ground between monolithic applications and microservices. Think of them as autonomous business units that include everything from the user interface to the database. They're larger than typical microservices but more focused and manageable than monoliths.

Key Characteristics of SCS:

  • Complete vertical slices of functionality
  • Independent data storage for each system
  • Minimal synchronous communication between systems
  • Event-driven architecture for data sharing
  • Team ownership of entire features


Real-World Success: 

Many organizations have successfully modernized their legacy systems using the SCS approach. Instead of breaking systems into dozens of tiny microservices, they create focused, self-contained business units that can evolve independently.

Key Benefits:

  • Teams own their complete stack (UI to database)
  • Changes can be made safely and incrementally
  • Systems communicate through simple events
  • Each unit scales based on its actual needs

This approach has consistently shown measurable improvements in deployment speed and team efficiency, with many organizations reporting significant reductions in coordination overhead and faster time-to-market for new features.



Implementation Strategies

When considering SCS implementation, remember these key points:

  1. Start Gradually: Use the Strangler Fig Pattern to replace parts of your system incrementally rather than attempting a complete rewrite.
  2. Focus on Data Independence: While systems may need to share data, use messages / events rather than real-time API calls. For example, product information doesn't need to propagate instantly across all systems.
  3. Maintain Clear Boundaries: Share technical components (like UI libraries) but keep business logic within each system.
  4. Embrace Event-Driven Communication: Use message brokers like Kafka or ActiveMQ for inter-system communication instead of synchronous APIs.


Is SCS Right for Your Organization?

SCS might be particularly suitable if:

  • You have distinct business domains that operate independently
  • Different parts of your system have varying scalability needs
  • You want to modernize your system incrementally
  • Your teams can own and maintain full-stack features
  • Real-time consistency isn't critical for all operations

Conclusion

While microservices have their place, Self-Contained Systems offer a pragmatic alternative that might better suit many organizations. They provide the benefits of modularity without the extreme complexity of fine-grained microservices. The key to successful software architecture isn't following trendsâ€”it's choosing the right level of modularity for your specific business context.

Remember: The goal isn't to be either monolithic or micro; it's to create maintainable, scalable systems that serve your business needs effectively. SCS might just be the sweet spot you've been looking for.

For more information about Self-Contained Systems, refer to:

  • The official SCS documentation: scs-architecture.org
  • Martin Fowler's writings on architectural patterns: martinfowler.com
  • ThoughtWorks Technology Radar's coverage of SCS
  • "Pattern: Decompose by Subdomain" in microservices.io by Chris Richardson
  • Say Goodbye to Microservices, Say Hello to Self-Contained Systems

node.title: AI Threat or Opportunity?
node.content:
"We are embracing the AI era to be 10X more productive"

As a small tech team, let me give some insight as to how we leverage AI to be 10X productive and deliver quality at scale to our clients.

  • AI for ideation, architectural patterns, and to refine requirements. Today, we have many at our disposal; our favourites are #ChatGPT and #Gemini's voice-over capability - we love the interactive model. Personally, I chat with an AI friend over voice before going to bed to refine my thoughts and seek insights, and with a clear implementation plan to code and share thoughts with the team in the morning.
  • AI as a Pair Programmer Thanks to #GitHubCopilot in our bestie IDE #VSCODE. You must juggle #Claude 3.5 (preview ) and #GPT 4o to get the best out of it. One is more descriptive, and the other just likes to code.
                          

                                                        Besties VSCode - Copilot
             
 
                                                                Claude vs GPT 4o

  • AI as Testerâ€” At scale, we can generate unit tests, Postman collections for API testing, and a framework with Playwright for end-to-end testing. We leveraged this to create an end-to-end integration. tests - playwright for e2e automated tests, creating resources using Terraform and marrying it all with GitHub Actions.

e2e Integration Testing

  • AI as a DevOps peerâ€” able to containerize everything in minutes, no more "it works on mine though" k8SGPT has made managing the microservices orchestrate platform #k8s much easier. All code approaches and sophisticated pipelines.
  • I have always wished I had Kubernetes two decades ago at the start of my career. I probably wouldn't have lost my hair. :)

We are making the most of it across all three areas of focus here at AppNetWise

AI application - a few use cases where we started leveraging various AI models in the solutions/applications we are building.

  • Document AI for processing invoicing for debt case management and integration with accounting software.
  • AI Agent compliance and audit - SaaS System
  • Threat Modelling in deep tech anti-ransomware system - SaaS System

We are now able to release more features sprint over sprint.

Upskill for prompt engineering; then you have a bestie in need: "AI"

If you want to see things in action, lets connect@appnetwise.com over a flat white. Cheers

node.title: Understanding Net-Zero: A Key Solution in the Fight Against Climate Change
node.content:
As the impacts of climate change become increasingly apparent, the world is facing a critical moment in its history. With rising global temperatures, extreme weather events, and ecological degradation, urgent action is needed to mitigate the effects of climate change. Among the various strategies proposed, achieving net-zero emissions has emerged as a crucial goal in the fight against climate change.



The Importance of Net-Zero

Net-zero refers to the balance between the amount of greenhouse gases produced and removed from the atmosphere. It signifies that the total emissions released into the atmosphere are equal to the emissions removed through various means, such as carbon capture and storage or natural processes like afforestation. In essence, achieving net-zero emissions means minimizing the release of greenhouse gases and offsetting any remaining emissions to effectively neutralize the impact on the climate.

The Importance of Net-Zero

The urgency of achieving net-zero emissions cannot be overstated. Greenhouse gases, primarily carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), and nitrous oxide (N2O), trap heat in the Earthâ€™s atmosphere, leading to global warming and climate instability. By reducing emissions to net-zero, we can limit further temperature rise and mitigate the most severe consequences of climate change, such as sea-level rise, extreme weather events, and loss of biodiversity.

Moreover, transistioning to a net-zero economy offers numerous co-benefits beyond climate mitigation. It can spur innovation and drive investment in renewable energy, clean technologies, and sustainable practices, fostering economic growth and job creation. Additionally, reducing reliance on fossil fuels can enhance energy security, improve air quality, and promote public health.

Challenges and Solutions

Achieving net-zero emissions is a complex undertaking that requires coordinated efforts across all sectors of society. One of the primary challenges is decarbonizing key sectors such as energy, transportation, industry, and agriculture, which are responsible for the majority of greenhouse gas emissions. This involves transitioning to renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, electrifying transportation, implementing sustainable agricultural practices, and adopting carbon capture and storage technologies.

Furthermore, addressing social and equity considerations is crucial to ensure a just transition to a net-zero future. Vulnerable communities, particularly those disproportionately affected by climate change and environmental degradation, must be prioritized in the transition process. This includes providing support for workers in carbon-intensive industries, investing in disadvantaged communities, and fostering inclusive decision-making processes.

Government policies and international cooperation are essential drivers in the transition to net-zero emissions. Nations worldwide must set ambitious targets and implement robust policies to incentivize emission reductions and accelerate the adoption of clean technologies. Additionally, collaboration between governments, businesses, civil society, and research institutions is critical to sharing knowledge, mobilizing resources, and scaling up solutions on a global scale.

The Path Forward

While achieving net-zero emissions is undoubtedly a formidable challenge, it is also an opportunity to build a more sustainable, resilient, and equitable future for all. By embracing innovation, collaboration, and collective action, we can overcome the obstacles ahead and transition to a net-zero economy that safeguards the planet for future generations.

In conclusion, the pursuit of net-zero emissions represents a pivotal moment in humanityâ€™s response to the climate crisis. It requires bold leadership, decisive action, and unwavering commitment from all stakeholders. By working together, we can turn the vision of a net-zero future into reality and secure a livable planet for generations to come.

Happy Sustainability!

node.title: Dev Containers: A New Era in Development Environment
node.content:
Ever found yourself in the twilight zone of coding, where your code runs like a dream on your local machine but throws a tantrum in the actual environment? Ah, the classic â€œit works on my machineâ€ syndrome! Weâ€™ve all been there, havenâ€™t we? Diving deep into the abyss of debugging, only to discover that the culprit was a sneaky dependency mismatch. The joys of being a developer, right? 

Here comes our savior to help us with this: â€˜Dev Containersâ€™

Introduction

In the wild jungle of software development, a new species has emerged, rising above the rest in its versatility and adaptability. Meet the Dev Containers, the Swiss Army knife of development environments. Theyâ€™re like a genie in a bottle (or rather, a Docker container), ready to grant your every development wish! 

What are Dev Containers? 

Dev Containers are like your personal butler, serving you everything you need for your development work on a silver platter. Theyâ€™re Docker containers equipped with all the tools, dependencies, and even the code editor you need. No more â€œit works on my machineâ€ excuses because now everyoneâ€™s machine is the same!
Why Use Dev Containers? 

Dev Containers are like the superheroes of the development world:

1.Consistency: They ensure justice by making sure everyone in the team is playing by the same rules. 2.Isolation: They protect your projects from each other, like a superhero protecting the city from villains. 
3.Reproducibility: They can clone themselves faster than a speeding bullet, making it easy to replicate your development environment. 
4.Automation: They can set up your development environment in a flash, saving the day by saving you time. 

Prerequisites for Dev Containers 

Before you can start using Dev Containers, you need to have certain prerequisites in place: 

1.Docker: You need Docker installed and running on your machine. After all, Dev Containers are Docker containers. 
2.VS Code: You need Visual Studio Code, which has built-in support for Dev Containers. Itâ€™s like the Batmobile of code editors. 
3.Remote â€” Containers extension: This VS Code extension is what allows you to open any folder inside a Dev Container. 

Tools that Support Dev Containers

Currently, Visual Studio Code is the main IDE that supports Dev Containers out of the box with its Remote â€” Containers extension. However, the concept of containerized development environments is catching on, and we might see more IDEs supporting this in the future. 

 Follow this link for more Information â€” https://containers.dev/supporting 

Use Cases 

Letâ€™s look at some use cases of how you can use Dev Containers in different scenarios:

Node.js Development: You can set up a Dev Container with Node.js, npm, and your favorite code editor installed. You can also include a .nvmrc file to specify the Node.js version, ensuring everyone is using the same version.
 {
    "name": "My Dev Container",
    "build": {
        "dockerfile": "Dockerfile",
        "context": "..",
        "args": { "VARIANT": "3" }
    },
    "runArgs": [ "-u", "python" ],
    "settings": { 
        "terminal.integrated.shell.linux": "/bin/bash"
    },
    "extensions": ["ms-python.python"],
    "postCreateCommand": "echo 'Welcome to your Dev Container!'",
    "features": {
        "github": "insiders"
    },
    "forwardPorts": [5000],
    "containerEnv": {
        "MY_ENV_VAR": "my-value"
    },
    "remoteUser": "python"
  }
        
Multi-Service Applications: If your application consists of multiple services (e.g., a front-end and a back-end), you can use Docker Compose to define multiple containers and include a devcontainer.json file to specify how they should be set up. 


{
    "name": "Multi-Service Application",
    "dockerComposeFile": "docker-compose.yml",
    "service": "app",
    "workspaceFolder": "/workspace",
    "extensions": ["dbaeumer.vscode-eslint"],
    "postCreateCommand": "npm install",
    "forwardPorts": [3000, 5000],
    "containerEnv": {
        "NODE_ENV": "development"
    },
    "remoteUser": "node"
}

Testing Across Different Environments: You can have multiple devcontainer.json files, each specifying a different environment (e.g., different versions of a language or library), allowing you to test your application across different environments easily. 

{
    "name": "Python 3",
    "build": {
        "dockerfile": "Dockerfile",
        "context": "..",
        "args": { "VARIANT": "3" }
    },
    "runArgs": [ "-u", "python" ],
    "settings": { 
        "terminal.integrated.shell.linux": "/bin/bash"
    },
    "extensions": ["ms-python.python"]
}
{
    "name": "Python 2",
    "build": {
        "dockerfile": "Dockerfile",
        "context": "..",
        "args": { "VARIANT": "2" }
    },
    "runArgs": [ "-u", "python" ],
    "settings": { 
        "terminal.integrated.shell.linux": "/bin/bash"
    },
    "extensions": ["ms-python.python"]
}
In this example, you can set the `VARIANT` argument to install different Python versions. 

Conclusion 

Dev Containers are revolutionizing the way we approach software development. They offer a level of flexibility, consistency, and reproducibility that was previously unheard of. Whether youâ€™re a solo developer working on a side project or part of a large team working on a complex application, Dev Containers can make your life easier. 

 Remember, the best way to understand Dev Containers is to dive in and start using them. So why not give it a try on your next project? You might just find itâ€™s the best decision youâ€™ve made for your development workflow!

References
  • https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/devcontainers/containers
  • https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/devcontainers/create-dev-container
  • https://containers.dev/
  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/shows/beginners-series-to-dev-containers/

For more insights and updates, feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn. Stay tuned for more exciting content!

node.title: ELK in Kubernetes Production
node.content:
Introduction

Are you looking to harness the power of Elasticsearch for storing and searching through large volumes of textual data, coupled with the visualization capabilities of Kibana? Look no further than Kubernetes, the leading container orchestrator. In this guide, weâ€™ll walk you through the process of deploying Elasticsearch and Kibana on Kubernetes, leveraging best practices and industry-standard tools like Helm.

Understanding Elasticsearch and Kubernetes

Elasticsearch is a distributed, scalable search engine designed to handle large volumes of data efficiently. Itâ€™s perfect for scenarios like log aggregation, metrics analysis, and full-text search. On the other hand, Kubernetes is a container orchestrator that simplifies the deployment and management of containerized applications, providing scalability and resilience.

Why Deploy Elasticsearch on Kubernetes?

Running Elasticsearch on Kubernetes offers several advantages. Kubernetes provides easy scalability, simplified management, and consistent deployment across different environments. By leveraging Kubernetes features like StatefulSets and PersistentVolumes, you can ensure data persistence and high availability for your Elasticsearch cluster.

Elasticsearch Cluster Architecture:

The Elasticsearch cluster comprises three types of nodes:

â¦ Master nodes: Handle cluster-wide management and configuration.

â¦ Data nodes: Responsible for storing data and executing data-related operations like searches.

â¦ Client nodes: Route cluster requests to the master node and handle data-related requests to data nodes.

The recommended practice is to deploy a total of 7 pods in the Elasticsearch cluster: 3 Master node pods, 2 Data node pods, and 2 Client node pods. The diagram below illustrates the cluster architecture with these pods.

Data node pods are deployed as a StatefulSet with a headless service toe stable network identities. Master node pods are deployed as a ReplicaSet with a headless service, facilitating auto-discovery. Client node pods are also deployed as a ReplicaSet, but with an internal service that allows access to the Data nodes for read/write requests.

Memory Requirements for Deploying Elasticsearch on Kubernetes

When deploying Elasticsearch on Kubernetes, remember to allocate at least 4GB of memory to each Kubernetes node. To run smoothly, youâ€™ll need a minimum of 7 nodes. The default size for PersistentVolumeClaims (PVCs) in each Elasticsearch Pod is 30GB, determining your block storage needs. Since pods are managed within a StatefulSet, ensure you have 30GB of storage available for each additional pod you create. Dealing with PVCs can be complex, especially outside of cloud services, as manual deletion may be required. Issues like pod startup failures often result from insufficient storage or lingering old PVCs.

Deploying a 7-Pod Elasticsearch Cluster on Kubernetes with Helm

To configure a robust Elasticsearch cluster, we follow best practices to set up 7 Pods: 3 master Pods, 2 data Pods, and 2 client Pods. This setup ensures optimal performance and reliability.

Start by running the Helm install command without any additional parameters:


helm install --name elasticsearch elastic/elasticsearch

Next, upgrade the Elasticsearch Pods to increase their number and assign specific roles. Create three YAML configuration files for this purpose:

 Master Pods Configuration:


# master.yaml
---
clusterName: "elasticsearch"
nodeGroup: "master"
roles:
  master: "true"
  ingest: "false"
  data: "false"
replicas: 3

Data Pods Configuration:


# data.yaml
--
clusterName: "elasticsearch"
nodeGroup: "data"
roles:
  master: "false"
  ingest: "true"
  data: "true"
replicas: 2

Clients Pods Configuration: 


# client.yaml
---
clusterName: "elasticsearch"
nodeGroup: "client"
roles:
  master: "false"
  ingest: "false"
  data: "false"
replicas: 2
service:
  type: "LoadBalancer"

Execute the upgrade command three times, using each YAML config file: 


Rhelm upgrade --wait --timeout=600 --install \
  --values ./master.yaml elasticsearch elastic/elasticsearch

helm upgrade --wait --timeout=600 --install \
  --values ./data.yaml elasticsearch elastic/elasticsearch

helm upgrade --wait --timeout=600 --install \
  --values ./client.yaml elasticsearch elastic/elasticsearch

The upgrade process might take a while. Once completed, verify the status of your resources: 

kubectl get all

You should see output similar to this: 

# Pods
NAME                          READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
pod/elasticsearch-client-0    1/1     Running   0          10m
pod/elasticsearch-client-1    1/1     Running   0          10m
pod/elasticsearch-data-0      1/1     Running   0          11m
pod/elasticsearch-data-1      1/1     Running   0          11m
pod/elasticsearch-master-0    1/1     Running   0          8m27s
pod/elasticsearch-master-1    1/1     Running   0          8m27s
pod/elasticsearch-master-2    1/1     Running   0          8m27s

# Services
NAME                                    TYPE           CLUSTER-IP       EXTERNAL-IP     PORT(S)                         AGE
service/elasticsearch-client            LoadBalancer   10.245.114.89    <YOUR_IP>       9200:32366/TCP,9300:31427/TCP   10m
service/elasticsearch-client-headless   ClusterIP      None              <NONE>         9200/TCP,9300/TCP               10m
service/elasticsearch-data              ClusterIP      10.245.116.115    <NONE>         9200/TCP,9300/TCP               11m
service/elasticsearch-data-headless     ClusterIP      None              <NONE>         9200/TCP,9300/TCP               11m
service/elasticsearch-master            ClusterIP      10.245.220.94     <NONE>         9200/TCP,9300/TCP               8m27s
service/elasticsearch-master-headless   ClusterIP      None              <NONE>         9200/TCP,9300/TCP               8m27s
service/kubernetes                      ClusterIP      10.245.0.1        <NONE>         443/TCP                         4h5m

# StatefulSets
NAME                             READY   AGE
statefulset.apps/elasticsearch-client   2/2     10m
statefulset.apps/elasticsearch-data     2/2     11m
statefulset.apps/elasticsearch-master   3/3     8m28s

To ensure everything is working, use curl to check the Elasticsearch endpoint: 

curl http://<YOUR_IP>/_cluster/state?pretty

Your cluster should now be ready to handle production workloads efficiently. If you encounter issues with larger clusters, consider configuring readiness probes to verify that your Elasticsearch Pods are ready to accept traffic.

How to Deploy Kibana on Kubernetes:

Deploying Kibana on Kubernetes allows you to visualize and manage your Elasticsearch data easily. Follow these steps to get Kibana up and running on your Kubernetes cluster.

Prerequisites

A running Elasticsearch cluster on Kubernetes.

Helm installed and configured.

Steps to Deploy Kibana

Add the Helm Chart for Kibana:

Use the official Helm chart to install Kibana. Run the following command, making sure to replace <CLIENT_SERVICE_NAME> with the name of your Elasticsearch client service. If you followed the 7-Pod Elasticsearch guide, the service name would be elasticsearch-client.


helm repo add bitnami https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami

helm install --name elasticsearch --set \
name=elasticsearch,master.replicas=3,coordinating.service.type=LoadBalancer bitnami/elasticsearch

Verify the Deployment:

After running the Helm command, check to ensure that Kibana is running properly by listing all resources:


[Output]

NAME                                                                 READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE

replicaset.apps/elasticsearch-elasticsearch-coordinating-only-694b5f94f8   2         2         2       3m55s

Access Kibana:

Open your web browser and navigate to http://< YOUR KIBANA IP>:5601. You should see the Kibana interface, where you can start visualizing your Elasticsearch data.
